niftoolsxml.basic: A boolean; 32-bit from 4.0.0.2, and 8-bit from 4.1.0.1 on.
A 16-bit (signed?) integer, which is used in the header to refer to a particular object type in a object type string array. The upper bit appears to be a flag used for PhysX block types.

A 32-bit integer that stores the version in hexadecimal format with each byte representing a number in the version string.
Some widely-used versions and their hex representation: 4.0.0.2: 0x04000002 4.1.0.12: 0x0401000C 4.2.0.2: 0x04020002 4.2.1.0: 0x04020100 4.2.2.0: 0x04020200 10.0.1.0: 0x0A000100 10.1.0.0: 0x0A010000 10.2.0.0: 0x0A020000 20.0.0.4: 0x14000004 20.0.0.5: 0x14000005
A 16-bit integer, used for bit flags. Function varies by object type.

A variable length string that ends with a newline character (0x0A). The string starts as follows depending on the version:
Version <= 10.0.1.0: 'NetImmerse File Format' Version >= 10.1.0.0: 'Gamebryo File Format'
A variable length string that ends with a newline character (0x0A).
A signed 32-bit integer, referring to a object before this one in the hierarchy. Examples: Bones, gravity objects.
A signed 32-bit integer, used to refer to another object; -1 means no reference. These should always point down the hierarchy. Other types are used for indexes that point to objects higher up.
A 32-bit unsigned integer, used to refer to strings in a NiStringPalette.
A 32-bit unsigned integer, used to refer to strings in the header.
niftoolsxml.bitflags: Describes the options for the accum root on NiControllerSequence. X Translation will be accumulated. Y Translation will be accumulated. Z Translation will be accumulated. X Rotation will be accumulated. Y Rotation will be accumulated. Z Rotation will be accumulated. +X is front facing. (Default) +Y is front facing. +Z is front facing. -X is front facing.
niftoolsxml.enum: Describes how the vertex colors are blended with the filtered texture color. Replaces existing color For placing images on the object like stickers. Modulates existing color. (Default) PS2 Only. Function Unknown. Parallax Flag in some Oblivion meshes.

The type of texture. The basic texture used by most meshes. Used to darken the model with false lighting. Combined with base map for added detail. Usually tiled over the mesh many times for close-up view. Allows the specularity (glossyness) of an object to differ across its surface. Creates a glowing effect. Basically an incandescence map. Used to make the object appear to have more detail than it really does. Used to make the object appear to have more detail than it really does. Parallax map. For placing images on the object like stickers. For placing images on the object like stickers. For placing images on the object like stickers. For placing images on the object like stickers.

The type of animation interpolation (blending) that will be used on the associated key frames. Use linear interpolation. Use quadratic interpolation. Forward and back tangents will be stored. Use Tension Bias Continuity interpolation. Tension, bias, and continuity will be stored. For use only with rotation data. Separate X, Y, and Z keys will be stored instead of using quaternions. Step function. Used for visibility keys in NiBoolData.

Bethesda Havok(hkpMoppCode::BuildType). A byte describing if MOPP Data is organized into chunks (PS3) or not (PC) Organized in chunks for PS3. Not organized in chunks for PC. (Default) Build type not set yet.
Target platform for NiPersistentSrcTextureRendererData (later than 30.1).
Target renderer for NiPersistentSrcTextureRendererData (until 30.1).

Describes the pixel format used by the NiPixelData object to store a texture. 24-bit RGB. 8 bits per red, blue, and green component. 32-bit RGB with alpha. 8 bits per red, blue, green, and alpha component. 8-bit palette index. 8-bit palette index with alpha. DXT1 compressed texture. DXT3 compressed texture. DXT5 compressed texture. (Deprecated) 24-bit noninterleaved texture, an old PS2 format. Uncompressed dU/dV gradient bump map. Uncompressed dU/dV gradient bump map with luma channel representing shininess. Generic descriptor for any renderer-specific format not described by other formats. Generic descriptor for formats with 1 component. Generic descriptor for formats with 2 components. Generic descriptor for formats with 3 components. Generic descriptor for formats with 4 components. Indicates the NiPixelFormat is meant to be used on a depth/stencil surface.
Describes whether pixels have been tiled from their standard row-major format to a format optimized for a particular platform.
Describes the pixel format used by the NiPixelData object to store a texture.
Describes how each pixel should be accessed on NiPixelFormat.

Describes the color depth in an NiTexture. Texture is in 8-bit palettized format. Texture is in 16-bit high color format. Texture is in 32-bit true color format. Texture is compressed. Texture is a grayscale bump map. Texture is in 4-bit palettized format. Use default setting.
Describes how mipmaps are handled in an NiTexture. Texture does not use mip maps. Texture uses mip maps. Use default setting.
Describes how transparency is handled in an NiTexture. No alpha. 1-bit alpha. Interpolated 4- or 8-bit alpha. Use default setting.

Describes the availiable texture clamp modes, i.e. the behavior of UV mapping outside the [0,1] range. Clamp in both directions. Clamp in the S(U) direction but wrap in the T(V) direction. Wrap in the S(U) direction but clamp in the T(V) direction. Wrap in both directions.

Describes the availiable texture filter modes, i.e. the way the pixels in a texture are displayed on screen. Nearest neighbor. Uses nearest texel with no mipmapping. Bilinear. Linear interpolation with no mipmapping. Trilinear. Linear intepolation between 8 texels (4 nearest texels between 2 nearest mip levels). Nearest texel on nearest mip level. Linear interpolates nearest texel between two nearest mip levels. Linear interpolates on nearest mip level. Anisotropic filtering. One or many trilinear samples depending on anisotropy.

Describes how to apply vertex colors for NiVertexColorProperty. Emissive, ambient, and diffuse colors are all specified by the NiMaterialProperty. Emissive colors are specified by the source vertex colors. Ambient+Diffuse are specified by the NiMaterialProperty. Ambient+Diffuse colors are specified by the source vertex colors. Emissive is specified by the NiMaterialProperty. (Default)
Describes which lighting equation components influence the final vertex color for NiVertexColorProperty. Emissive. Emissive + Ambient + Diffuse. (Default)
The animation cyle behavior. Loop Reverse Clamp
The force field type. Wind (fixed direction) Point (fixed origin)

Determines the way the billboard will react to the camera. Billboard mode is stored in lowest 3 bits although Oblivion vanilla nifs uses values higher than 7. Align billboard and camera forward vector. Minimized rotation. Align billboard and camera forward vector while allowing rotation around the up axis. Align billboard and camera forward vector. Non-minimized rotation. Billboard forward vector always faces camera ceneter. Minimized rotation. Billboard forward vector always faces camera ceneter. Non-minimized rotation.
The billboard will only rotate around its local Z axis (it always stays in its local X-Y plane). The billboard will only rotate around the up axis (same as ROTATE_ABOUT_UP?).
Describes stencil buffer test modes for NiStencilProperty. Always false. Ref value is ignored. VRef VBuf VRef = VBuf VRef VBuf VRef VBuf VRef VBuf VRef VBuf Always true. Buffer is ignored.

Describes the actions which can occur as a result of tests for NiStencilProperty. Keep the current value in the stencil buffer. Write zero to the stencil buffer. Write the reference value to the stencil buffer. Increment the value in the stencil buffer. Decrement the value in the stencil buffer. Bitwise invert the value in the stencil buffer.

Describes the face culling options for NiStencilProperty. Application default, chooses between DRAW_CCW or DRAW_BOTH. Draw only the triangles whose vertices are ordered CCW with respect to the viewer. (Standard behavior) Draw only the triangles whose vertices are ordered CW with respect to the viewer. (Effectively flips faces) Draw all triangles, regardless of orientation. (Effectively force double-sided)

Describes Z-buffer test modes for NiZBufferProperty. "Less than" = closer to camera, "Greater than" = further from camera. Always true. Buffer is ignored. VRef VBuf VRef = VBuf VRef VBuf VRef VBuf VRef VBuf VRef VBuf Always false. Ref value is ignored.
Describes alpha blend modes for NiAlphaProperty.

Bethesda Havok, based on hkpMotion::MotionType. Motion type of a rigid body determines what happens when it is simulated. Invalid A fully-simulated, movable rigid body. At construction time the engine checks the input inertia and selects MO_SYS_SPHERE_INERTIA or MO_SYS_BOX_INERTIA as appropriate. Simulation is performed using a sphere inertia tensor. This is the same as MO_SYS_SPHERE_INERTIA, except that simulation of the rigid body is "softened". Simulation is performed using a box inertia tensor. This is the same as MO_SYS_BOX_INERTIA, except that simulation of the rigid body is "softened". Simulation is not performed as a normal rigid body. The keyframed rigid body has an infinite mass when viewed by the rest of the system. (used for creatures) This motion type is used for the static elements of a game scene, e.g. the landscape. Faster than MO_SYS_KEYFRAMED at velocity 0. (used for weapons) A box inertia motion which is optimized for thin boxes and has less stability problems A specialized motion used for character controllers

Bethesda Havok, based on hkpRigidBodyDeactivator::DeactivatorType. Deactivator Type determines which mechanism Havok will use to classify the body as deactivated. Invalid This will force the rigid body to never deactivate. Tells Havok to use a spatial deactivation scheme. This makes use of high and low frequencies of positional motion to determine when deactivation should occur.

Bethesda Havok, based on hkpRigidBodyCinfo::SolverDeactivation. A list of possible solver deactivation settings. This value defines how aggressively the solver deactivates objects. Note: Solver deactivation does not save CPU, but reduces creeping of movable objects in a pile quite dramatically. Invalid No solver deactivation. Very conservative deactivation, typically no visible artifacts. Normal deactivation, no serious visible artifacts in most cases. Fast deactivation, visible artifacts. Very fast deactivation, visible artifacts.

Bethesda Havok, based on hkpCollidableQualityType. Describes the priority and quality of collisions for a body, e.g. you may expect critical game play objects to have solid high-priority collisions so that they never sink into ground, or may allow penetrations for visual debris objects. Notes: - Fixed and keyframed objects cannot interact with each other. - Debris can interpenetrate but still responds to Bullet hits. - Critical objects are forced to not interpenetrate. - Moving objects can interpenetrate slightly with other Moving or Debris objects but nothing else. Automatically assigned to MO_QUAL_FIXED, MO_QUAL_KEYFRAMED or MO_QUAL_DEBRIS Static body. Animated body with infinite mass. Low importance bodies adding visual detail. Moving bodies which should not penetrate or leave the world, but can. Gameplay critical bodies which cannot penetrate or leave the world under any circumstance. Fast-moving bodies, such as projectiles. For user. For use with rigid body character controllers.
Moving bodies with infinite mass which should report contact points and TOI collisions against all other bodies.
Describes the type of gravitational force.

Describes which aspect of the NiTextureTransform the NiTextureTransformController will modify. Control the translation of the U coordinates. Control the translation of the V coordinates. Control the rotation of the coordinates. Control the scale of the U coordinates. Control the scale of the V coordinates.
Describes the decay function of bomb forces. No decay. Linear decay. Exponential decay.
Describes the symmetry type of bomb forces. Spherical Symmetry. Cylindrical Symmetry. Planar Symmetry.

Controls the way the a particle mesh emitter determines the starting speed and direction of the particles that are emitted. Uses the normals of the meshes to determine staring velocity. Starts particles with a random velocity. Uses the emission axis to determine initial particle direction?

Controls which parts of the mesh that the particles are emitted from. Emit particles from the vertices of the mesh. Emit particles from the center of the faces of the mesh. Emit particles from the center of the edges of the mesh. Perhaps randomly emit particles from anywhere on the faces of the mesh? Perhaps randomly emit particles from anywhere on the edges of the mesh?

The type of information that is stored in a texture used by an NiTextureEffect. Apply a projected light texture. Each light effect is summed before multiplying by the base texture. Apply a projected shadow texture. Each shadow effect is multiplied by the base texture. Apply an environment map texture. Added to the base texture and light/shadow/decal maps. Apply a fog map texture. Alpha channel is used to blend the color channel with the base texture.

Determines the way that UV texture coordinates are generated. Use planar mapping. Use perspective mapping. Use spherical mapping. Use specular cube mapping. For NiSourceCubeMap only. Use diffuse cube mapping. For NiSourceCubeMap only.

enum.name: EndianType
enum.option: The numbers are stored in big endian format, such as those used by PowerPC Mac processors.
The numbers are stored in little endian format, such as those used by Intel and AMD x86 processors.

niftoolsxml.enum: Used by NiMaterialColorControllers to select which type of color in the controlled object that will be animated. Control the ambient color. Control the diffuse color. Control the specular color. Control the self illumination color.
Used by NiLightColorControllers to select which type of color in the controlled object that will be animated. Control the diffuse color. Control the ambient color.

Used by NiGeometryData to control the volatility of the mesh. Consistency Type is masked to only the upper 4 bits (0xF000). Dirty mask is the lower 12 (0x0FFF) but only used at runtime. Mutable Mesh Static Mesh Volatile Mesh
Describes the way that NiSortAdjustNode modifies the sorting behavior for the subtree below it. Inherit. Acts identical to NiNode. Disables sort on all geometry under this node.

The propagation mode controls scene graph traversal during collision detection operations for NiCollisionData. Propagation only occurs as a result of a successful collision. (Deprecated) Propagation only occurs as a result of a failed collision. Propagation always occurs regardless of collision result. Propagation never occurs regardless of collision result.

The collision mode controls the type of collision operation that is to take place for NiCollisionData. Use Bounding Box Use Triangles Use Alternate Bounding Volumes Indicates that no collision test should be made. Use NiBound
Bethesda Havok(hkpMaterial::ResponseType). Invalid Response Do normal collision resolution No collision resolution is performed but listeners are called Do nothing, ignore all the results.

Bethesda Havok. Collision filter info representing Layer, Flags, Part Number, and Group all combined into one uint. The layer the collision belongs to. The layer the collision belongs to. The layer the collision belongs to.
FLAGS are stored in highest 3 bits: Bit 7: sets the LINK property and controls whether this body is physically linked to others. Bit 6: turns collision off (not used for Layer BIPED). Bit 5: sets the SCALED property.
PART NUMBER is stored in bits 0-4. Used only when Layer is set to BIPED.

A list of shapes. However, - The sub shapes must ALL be convex: Sphere, Capsule, Cylinder, Convex Vertices, Convex Transform - The radius of all shapes must be identical - The number of sub shapes is restricted to 255 - The number of vertices of each sub shape is restricted to 255
For this reason you most likely cannot combine Sphere Shapes, Capsule Shapes, and Convex Vertices Shapes, as their Radius values differ in function. (Sphere/Capsule radius = physical size, CVS radius = padding/shell)

enum.name: PSLoopBehavior
enum.option: Key times map such that the first key occurs at the birth of the particle, and times later than the last key get the last key value.
Key times map such that the last key occurs at the death of the particle, and times before the initial key time get the value of the initial key.
Scale the animation to fit the particle lifetime, so that the first key is age zero, and the last key comes at the particle death.
The time is converted to one within the time range represented by the keys, as if the key sequence loops forever in the past and future.
The time is reflection looped, as if the keys played forward then backward the forward then backward etc for all time.

Orientation marker for Skyrim's inventory view. How to show the nif in the player's inventory. Typically attached to the root node of the nif tree. If not present, then Skyrim will still show the nif in inventory, using the default values. Name should be 'INV' (without the quotes). For rotations, a short of "4712" appears as "4.712" but "959" appears as "0.959" meshes\weapons\daedric\daedricbowskinned.nif
